description: Redevelopment of existing garage and petrol filling station and erection of three storey building comprising of 8 no. self contained units with associated car parking and landscaping
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the windows shown as serving bathrooms at first and second floor levels in the north-eastern (rear) elevation shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or roof lights at first floor level or above in the north-western (flank) or south-eastern (flank) elevations shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development to which this permission relates, a strategy to deal with the potential risks associated with any contamination of the site shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. This strategy shall include the following components:(i) A preliminary risk assessment which has identified: all previous uses; potential contaminants associated with those uses; a conceptual model of the site indicating sources, pathways and receptors; and potentially unacceptable risks arising from contamination at the site.(ii) A site investigation scheme (based on 7(i) above) to provide information for a detailed assessment of the risk to all receptors that may be affected, including those off site.(iii) The results of the site investigation and the detailed risk assessment referred to in (ii) and, based on this, an options appraisal and remediation strategy giving full details of the remediation measures required and how they are to be undertaken.(iv) A verification plan providing details of the data that will be collected in order to demonstrate that the works set out in the remediation strategy in (iii) are complete and identifying any requirements for longer-term monitoring of pollutant linkages, maintenance and arrangements for contingency action.Any changes to these components will require the written consent of the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in full.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. These details are required prior to commencement of development in the interests of safety.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a verification report demonstrating the completion of works set out in the approved remediation strategy and the effectiveness of the remediation shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The report shall include results of sampling and monitoring carried out in accordance with the approved verification plan to demonstrate that the site remediation criteria have been met.Reason: To ensure that the site does not pose any further risk to human health or the water environment by demonstrating that the requirements of the approved verification plan have been met and that remediation of the site is complete, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

If, during development, contamination not previously identified is found to be present at the site then no further development (unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority) shall be carried out until a remediation strategy detailing how this contamination will be dealt with has been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The remediation strategy shall be implemented as approved.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from previously unidentified contamination sources at the development site, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No drainage systems involving the infiltration of surface water into the ground shall be implemented on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from mobilised contaminants, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No piling or other foundation designs involving penetrative methods shall be implemented on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority. If such methods are proposed, a risk assessment, demonstrating that there would be no resultant unacceptable risk to groundwater shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The proposed development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details.Reason: To ensure that the development does not contribute to, put at unacceptable risk from, or adversely affected by unacceptable levels of water pollution from mobilised contaminants, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a scheme to enhance the nature conservation interest of the site shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall then be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development.Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy 7.19 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a car park management plan (detailing how spaces will be allocated, how the use of the car park will be controlled, the signage necessary to direct pedestrians and vehicles) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved plan.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the vehicular crossover(s) as shown on the approved plans shall be provided (including reinstating the footway to the satisfaction of the local planning authority) and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure proper vehicular access to the site in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any redundant accesses to the site shall be stopped up and the footway reinstated to the satisfaction of the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure proper vehicular access to the site in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used)xx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

Prior to the beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, pedestrian/vehicular intervisibility splays of 2.8m x 3.3m shall have been provided in each direction where the access meets the back edge of footway and shall be permanently retained free from any obstruction to visibility higher than 1.0m above ground level.Reason: In the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, one car parking space shall be provided with active provision for electric vehicle charging points and one further space shall be provided with passive charging points and thereafter permanently retained.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The proposed upstand on the original outrigger would fall under Class B.

Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building.ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of single storey rear and first floor side extensions.Consultation5 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers;- The impact of the development on floodingCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed single storey extension would project 3.2m (depth) x 4m (width) from the rear wall of the existing building, with a flat roof design (Xm in height). The extension would integrate and align with the existing rear extension and incorporate 2 lantern roof lights and bifold doors across the rear elevation.The first floor extension would be set back 800mm from the front elevation of the host building, would be 1.4m wide and 7m in depth to align with the existing rear wall, and setback from the ground floor below as it relates to No.96 Somerset, ensuring both a physical and visual separation of the built form. The external materials proposed are to match with the existing building. The proposed roof form would relate well to the host property and would not exceed the ridge of the existing main roof, in accordance with Policy Guidance 36. It is considered that the proposed extensions would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition in relation to the host dwelling. Officers also note that the neighbouring property at No.96 Somerset Avenue has obtained planning permission 20/03162/HOU for a similar development at both ground and first floor levels.Having regard to the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Nos.96 and 100 Somerset Avenue are the principal properties to be considered in relation to amenity.  Due to the setback of the proposed first floor side extension there would be no unacceptable loss of light or outlook to neighbouring habitable rooms of No.96 Somerset Avenue. Existing windows to the side elevation of No.96 Somerset serve stairwell areas, and are proposed to be removed by planning permission 20/01362/HOU. Notwithstanding this, the proposed window to the side elevation at first floor level would serve a stairwell, and will be obscured by condition.With regards to No. 100 Somerset Avenue there would be no adverse impact due to the nature and siting of the proposals. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Flood RiskThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The Flood Risk Form submitted by the applicant indicates that the proposed extension would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012). ConclusionThe proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

The site comprises a commercial unit located on the ground floor of a terraced property forming a parade of shops, with residential properties on the floors above. 20 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 4 objections have been received relating to:- Access or traffic problems;- Car park issues;- Fumes;- Noise; and,- Unacceptable or incompatible use.The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.RBK Environmental Health Officer - The proposal should be refused unless an acoustic report is submitted demonstrating that the noise front he kitchen extract system would be within the recommended guidelines. Full details with calculations of the proposed extraction system should be submitted to demonstrate that odour and noise would be in compliance with relevant guidelines. The applicant should be aware that within the drawing submitted the fan is located before the carbon filter and pre-filter while it would be expected that the fan is after both these filters and the pre-filter is before the carbon filter to protect it. The proposed sound insulation is acceptable, but would request trading hours to cease at 11pm Monday to Saturday and 10pm Sundays and Bank Holidays.Public Health Nutritionist - The site would be in close proximity to both Tolworth Girls School and Tolworth Hospital, as such restrictions should be placed on access to unhealthy options. Takeaways should not be within 400 metres walking distance from entrances and exits of an existing or proposed primary or secondary school. The applicant has not made reference to the type of food to be served which is of key relevance to the proposal.The key areas of assessment are:- The principle of the development; - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.Principal of DevelopmentOfficers note that whilst the site falls within a small parade of commercial units, it does not form part of a designated Local Centre. It is understood that it last operated as a cafe. In relation to surrounding uses the proposed change of use in this case would not be incompatible or dissimilar to the existing. Neither would it result in a predominance of Sui Generis uses in the area.Officers also note that the proposed fast food takeaway would not sit within 400m walking distance from any entrances or exits of an existing or proposed primary or secondary school and therefore would be compliant with the objectives of Policy DM21 of the Core Strategy.The applicant asserts that the premises has been vacant for a year, although no evidence has been submitted to substantiate this. Notwithstanding, the proposal is considered not to result in a loss of employment land/floorspace and would therefore be compliant with the objectives of Policy DM17 of the Core Strategy.DesignThe proposed external changes would involve the installation of an extraction flue to the rear elevation of the property. It would not extend any more than 1m above the highest window head and as such officers consider the impact to the character to the surrounding area to be minimal. No changes are proposed to the front elevation of the property. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesIn terms of controlling smells and odours the applicant has failed to provide an acoustic report, or details of the extraction system and as such has failed to demonstrate how smells and odours would be controlled on site and how the proposed development would not cause harm to the residential amenities of the neighbouring occupiers. Further, officers note that the proposed fan would be located before the carbon filter and pre-filter, where it is expected to be located after the filter and pre-filter. The proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.It is considered that in the event of an approval and subject to a condition to control the hours of operation, the proposed development would not result in undue noise or disturbance.Highways and TransportationWhile the application site has a PTAL Score of 1b (very low), officers consider that the change of use would not result in a significant intensification of activities on site and or trip generation. Despite the lack of parking provision associated with the site and the location of a bus stop on the road to the front of the premises, there would be sufficient opportunities for short stay parking (commensurate with the size and type of proposed use) on surrounding roads in close proximity of the site.  Therefore, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact upon on-street car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety over and above the existing use, thereby achieving compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10. ConclusionThe scheme under consideration involves the change of use to Hot Food Take-Away - Sui Generis Use Class from Retail unit - E(a) Use Class and the installation of an extractor flue pipe.The proposed development would have no adverse impacts on employment land and premises or health and well-being.  Neither would it have an unacceptable adverse impact upon character and appearance and or highways and transportation. These are all neutral matters.However, through the lack of an accoustic report or details of the proposed extraction system the applicant has failed to demonstrate how smells and odours would be controlled on site and how the proposed development would not cause harm to the residential amenities of the neighbouring occupiers. As such the proposal would fail to accord with policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012. Officers consider that this issue would significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits of granting permission, when assessed against the policies in the NPPF 2021 taken as a whole. It is therefore recommended that planning permission is refused.

It is noted that the original permission 17/12989/FUL is required to be implemented within 3 years of the grant of planning permission. This date has now passed. There remain a number of outstanding pre-commencement planning conditions which have not been discharged.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Objections:2 neighbour objections have been received and summarised as follows.- Inappropriate design/layout; and,- Noise.The objections have been addressed in the assessment. Surbiton CAAC have also objected to the siting of the A board. The co-Chairs of the Surbiton Neighbourhood Planning Committee have authorised officers to make a delegated decision in this case. Application SiteThe site comprises a ground floor commercial unit located in the designated Surbiton District Centre and the Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area. The host property is a locally listed building a non-designated heritage asset.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the proposed devleopment on heritage assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.Design and HeritageWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  Paragraphs 189 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is also considered that the tables and chairs, jumberellas and A board would not compete with and would be a subordinate addition to the host property, a locally listed building. The special architectural features and historic interest of the building would be preserved, the proposal would not create visual clutter and would sit comfortably in the foreground of the building, as well as provide visual interest and stimulus in the streetscene. As such, the proposed development would not result in any harm to the character or appearance of the area and would preserve the character and appearance of the Surbiton Town Conservation Area. It is considerd that the proposal would not impede the free flow of pedestrian movement in and around the site and the building would maintain access for all. The presence of an A board on site would be in keeping with that of other propeties in the road and would be removed daily when the unit is not in use and this would be secured by condition.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The seating area would be restricted by condition in terms of the hours in which it can be used 9.30am - 9.30pm Mon - Sat and 10.00am - 8.30pm Sun and Bank holidays. This is to mitigate noise pollution to neighbouring residential occupiers beyond unsociable hours.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of two storey side extension, part two storey rear extension, conversion of garage into habitable space and single storey outbuilding (office, cinema, storage and w.c) to rear gardenConsultationFive neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Highways and sustainable travelDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note that a number of surrounding properties already benefit from this type of side extension including neighbouring No 87 and No. 89 Hook Rise South. The proposed first floor side extension has been set back from front elevation and below the existing ridge height with a matching roof pitch to the existing. Access to the rear of the property has also been maintained to decrease the terracing effect. In relation to the proposed outbuilding officers note that a similar outbuilding has already been permitted.(21/01652/CPU dated 15.07.2021) The proposed outbuilding would be of the same footprint but will have a crown roof instead of a flat roof. As the outbuilding is to the rear of the property, officer could not identify any harm caused to the character and appearance of the area.  The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  In relation to neighbouring amenity the principle properties to be considered are No. 89 and No. 93 Hook Rise South. In relation to No. 89 Hook Rise South, due to the existing situation it is not consider the proposed two storey extension would lead to overbearing appearance or loss of light. In relation to No. 93 Hook Rise South, the Single storey element, due to its limited depth would also not lead to overbearing appearance or loss of light. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Car ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate two off street car parking spaces, therefore the proposal would comply with the Policy DM9 and DM10.Sustainable TravelPolicy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3, ensuring that a minimum of two short-stay and two long-stay cycle parking spaces are provided.Officer Comment: The proposed development would not result in the loss of access to the rear garden from the front of the property so despite the loss of the garage, secure cycle parking can still be achieved in the rear garden.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling. Although detached, the property is in close proximity to No. 85 St Albans Road.ProposalErection of part single storey and part two storey rear extension including creation of a light well. Rear piggy back roof extension with installation of 7no rooflights, 1no front and 3no rear gable windows to facilitate loft conversion. Associated changes to fenestrationThis application follows previously refused application 21/00046/HOU dated 22.03.2021 which was refused for the following reason:The lack of set-back from the front elevation and the excessive height of the proposed piggyback extension would result in a prominent and incongruous feature which would detract from the character and appearance of the existing site and surrounding area. The proposal is therefore considered contrary to the Kingston Residential Design SPD (2013), Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) and the NPPF (2019).This application seeks to address the previous reason for refusal.ConsultationEight neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Policy Guidance 40 (Piggyback Extensions) states that where the character of the property and wider streetscene allows, there may be some scope to obtain planning permission to construct a 'piggyback' extension where:-the extension is set back from the front elevation of the house by at least 4m;-the house is on a narrow plot and the side elevations are not highly visible from the street scene;-materials and detailing are selected to match or complement the original house;-the extension does not increase the height of the eaves and ridge by more than 1.3m;-the gaps between the first floor side elevations of neighbouring dwellings are no more than 2.1m to reduce the impact of the extension on the character of the streetscene; and-no dormer style roof extensions are proposed in addition to the piggyback extension.The proposed piggy back extension would be set back from the front elevation of the house by approximately 4m and would increase the height of the eaves and ridge by approximately 1.3 metres in compliance with Policy Guidance 40 of the Residential Design SPD (2013).  As such and in this specific regard the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. In terms of the other aspects of the proposal it is considered that there would be no unacceptable adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is acknowledged that there would be some loss of daylight/sunlight to a ground floor side elevation window at No. 85, however, the window in question would appear to be an obscurely glazed non-habitable bathroom window (ref: 19/01094/HOU). As such, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy to an unacceptable degree.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2.
