Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building located on the northern side of Sandal Road.ProposalPlanning permission is sought for the erection of a hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions with installation of 4no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.This application follows a lawful development certificate (21/00969/CPU) that was refused for the same development.Consultation3 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The planning history of the property- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Planning history of the application property is a material consideration. An application for permitted development (21/00969/CPU) was refused for the following reason: It has not been demonstrated, on the balance of probabilities, that the cubic content of the resulting roof space would not exceed the cubic content of the original roof space by more than 50 cubic metres. It has also not been confirmed that the materials would be similar in appearance to those used in the construction of the exterior of the existing dwellinghouse. The proposed development would fail to comply with part B1.(d) (ii) and condition B.2(a) of Class B, Part 1, Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).The current proposal makes no changes to the permitted development application.  The test therefore is whether this proposal is acceptable in its own right having regard to the parameters of the GPDO, in addition to other relevant policy guidance.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policies 39 and 40 of the Residential Design SPD state that when considering roof extension such as dormer windows and gable end extensions, that dormer windows are set down from the ridge line of the existing roof slope, set in form the sides and elves of the roof by 500mm and do not feature on the front roof slope. Gable end extensions are not usually appropriate as they are often at odds with the existing character of the (semi detached) property and upset the visual balance of the two houses when viewed in the context of other houses in the street or wider area. Officers consider that the proposed hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions, notably the former would alter the appearance of the property, and change the symmetry and visual balance of the application property and No.10 Sandal Road. However, it is a highly material consideration that both the hip to gable and rear dormer extensions, with a very minor amendment/reduction in cubic content, would likely fall within the parameters of permitted development and on the evidence before officers, there would be nothing to prevent the applicant from carrying out the development in this way. Taking account of the comparable fall-back position, officers consider that the proposal is, on balance, in accordance with policies D3 and HC1 of the London Plan and policies DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development, whilst not representing the best design and not following the design guidance in the Residential Design SPD, would, when viewed in light of the highly material consideration i.e. with a minor amendment, both the hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions would likely fall within the parameters of permitted development,  be no more harmful than such a similar development carried out under permitted development. On balance officers consider that the proposal is in accordance with policies D3 and HC1 of the London Plan and policies DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.There is an existing window at first floor level to the side elevation of No.12 Sandal Road. Outlook from this north facing window is already limited given its location (facing a brick wall) and separation distance from the application property. Officers note the lawful development certificate was refused on the grounds that the proposed hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension would exceed the cubic content of the original roof space by more than 50 cubic metres. However, with a minor reduction in the cubic content permitted development rights would apply. Taking this into account, although the proposal may result in some loss of light to the window in the side elevation of No. 12, the level of outlook from this window is unlikely to be any worse as a result of the current development, than experienced through the same proposal under permitted development. Windows to the proposed roof extensions are either rooflights or located to the rear elevation, with the outlook directed to the rear of the application property. Officers are therefore satisfied that the proposal would not appear overbearing or result in any undue loss of light to neighbouring occupiers. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.ConclusionOfficers consider that the proposed development would result in material harm to the character and appearance of the area. However, having regard to the permitted development fallback position, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with policies D3 and HC1 of the London Plan and policies DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy. Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

---OFFICER REPORT---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site and its planning history, the relevant legislation and guidance, considered any relevant case law, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents.Application SiteThe site comprises a single storey, brick-built building attached to the north-eastern end of a row of garages adjacent to Lakeside (a block of residential flats), Eaton Drive.ProposalThe application seeks a lawful development certificate for the existing use of the building as an estate office falling within Class E of Schedule 2 to the Use Classes Order.ConsultationN/A.LegislationThe application is made pursuant to Section 191 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).Section 191(2) of the Act reads:(2) For the purposes of this Act uses and operations are lawful at any time if—(a) no enforcement action may then be taken in respect of them (whether because they did not involve development or require planning permission or because the time for enforcement action has expired or for any other reason); and(b) they do not constitute a contravention of any of the requirements of any enforcement notice then in force.Section 191(4) of the Act reads:(4) If, on an application under this section, the local planning authority are provided with information satisfying them of the lawfulness at the time of the application of the use, operations or other matter described in the application, or that description as modified by the local planning authority or a description substituted by them, they shall issue a certificate to that effect; and in any other case they shall refuse the application.Section 171B of the Act reads:(1) Where there has been a breach of planning control consisting in the carrying out without planning permission of building, engineering, mining or other operations in, on, over or under land, no enforcement action may be taken after the end of the period of four years beginning with the date on which the operations were substantially completed.(2) Where there has been a breach of planning control consisting in the change of use of any building to use as a single dwellinghouse, no enforcement action may be taken after the end of the period of four years beginning with the date of the breach.(3) In the case of any other breach of planning control, no enforcement action may be taken after the end of the period of ten years beginning with the date of the breach.The Applicable TestIn light of the above, the test is whether, on the balance of probability, the building was used as an estate office falling within Class E of Schedule 2 to the Use Classes Order for a period of ten years ending with the date the application was made.GuidanceParagraph reference 17c-005-20140306 of the NPPG reads:An application needs to describe precisely what is being applied for (not simply the use class) and the land to which the application relates. Without sufficient or precise information, a local planning authority may be justified in refusing a certificate. This does not preclude another application being submitted later on, if more information can be produced.Paragraph reference 17c-006-20140306 of the NPPG reads:The applicant is responsible for providing sufficient information to support an application, although a local planning authority always needs to cooperate with an applicant who is seeking information that the authority may hold about the planning status of the land. A local planning authority is entitled to canvass evidence if it so wishes before determining an application. If a local planning authority obtains evidence, this needs to be shared with the applicant who needs to have the opportunity to comment on it and possibly produce counter-evidence. In the case of applications for existing use, if a local planning authority has no evidence itself, nor any from others, to contradict or otherwise make the applicant's version of events less than probable, there is no good reason to refuse the application, provided the applicant's evidence alone is sufficiently precise and unambiguous to justify the grant of a certificate on the balance of probability.Paragraph reference 17c-008-20140306 of the NPPG reads:There is no statutory requirement to consult third parties including parish councils or neighbours. It may, however, be reasonable for a local planning authority to seek evidence from these sources, if there is good reason to believe they may possess relevant information about the content of a specific application. Views expressed by third parties on the planning merits of the case, or on whether the applicant has any private rights to carry out the operation, use or activity in question, are irrelevant when determining the application.The EvidenceThe applicant has described the use of the building as an estate office and has stated that the building has been in this use since its construction in 1967. The applicant considers this use to fall within Class B1(a) of the Schedule to the Use Classes Order 1987 (as amended), as it existed prior to its amendment in September 2020. This former use class now makes up part of Class E of Schedule 2 to the Use Classes Order.Although the applicant has provided very little evidence to demonstrate that the building has been used as an estate office for the period of time stated, officers have no evidence to contradict this version of events and consequently do not dispute it. However, it is much more doubtful that this use falls within Class E. The applicant has not described the activities carried out from the building in any detail, but the typical purpose of an estate office is to assist with the management of an estate i.e. maintenance of the buildings and grounds, and providing general assistance to occupants. In other words, an estate office has a supporting function within a wider estate and in this sense, is functionally inseparable from that estate.On the available evidence, officers consider that this is the purpose the application building fulfills, i.e. it is ancillary to the wider use of the estate as a residential block of flats and associated amenities, which is a use falling within Class C3 of Schedule 1 to the Use Classes Order. It follows that, on the balance of probability, the building was not used for a use falling within Class E of Schedule 2 to the Use Classes Order for a period of ten years ending with the date the application was made. Accordingly, officers conclude that the application should be refused.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---END OF OFFICER REPORT---

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a semi detached residential dwelling.The buildings on site are not listed, or locally listed and the site does not fall within a conservation area. However, the site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability).ProposalThe application seeks the erection of a single storey side and rear extension.Consultation10 properties were notified of the proposal. 1 objection was received. The material issues raised are summarised as follows:- Excessive scale and depth;- Inappropriate form;- Fails to respect symmetry with adjoining property; and,- Terracing effect.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,-The impact of the proposed development on flood risk.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Flood RiskParagraph 167 of the NPPF states that when determining any planning applications, local planning authorities should ensure that flood risk is not increased elsewhere. Where appropriate, applications should be supported by a site-specific flood risk assessment. This includes all development within Flood Zones 2 and 3.Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: As stated above the application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. The Flood Risk Assessment submitted by the applicant indicates that floor levels within the proposed development would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would be implemented as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling within the Cranes Park  Local Area of Special Character. The site is not located within a Conservation Area and there are no Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) applicable to the site or neighbouring properties.ProposalErection of single storey side/rear extensionConsultationTwenty neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Cranes Park  Local Area of Special Character.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The rear of the property already benefits from a single storey rear extension. The proposal would be to infill the area to the rear of the property up to the boundary of No. 9 Lingfield Avenue.  Officers acknowledge the proposed works would be visible from Geneva Road. However, the existing rear extensions are already visible so no further harm has been identified to the character and appearance of the local area of special character. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The principle properties to be considered in relation to amenity are No. 9 and No. 13 Lingfield Road. In relation to No. 13, due to the existing situation it is not considered that the proposed infill extension would have a detrimental effect to the amenity. With regards to No. 9 Lingfield Avenue, Officers note that an application has also been submitted for a similar extension (21/01624/HOU) which would be built to the boundary of No. 11. It has been proposed that both extensions, if permitted will be built out at the same time. This would therefore result in no harm to the amenity of both properties as a result. This has been discussed with the applicant and in order to ensure both extensions are completed at the same time a pre commencement condition will be added if approved to secure this element of the build.  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
